itemContext.sbar:
S: John Smith, 72-year-old male, admitted at 07:00 today with right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Found down at home by his daughter. Last known well was yesterday at 22:00. 
B: History of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. Currently on warfarin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. 
A: At 09:00, patient is drowsy but arousable to verbal stimuli. Right-sided hemiparesis present. GCS is 13 (E3, V4, M6). BP 180/100, HR 92, RR 22, SpO2 94% on room air. Temperature 37.5째C. CT scan showed a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) ischemic stroke with some surrounding edema. Neurosurgeon consulted. 
R: Continue to monitor neurological status closely. Manage blood pressure per stroke protocol (maintain SBP <160). Administer prescribed medications. Elevate head of bed to 30 degrees. Prepare for possible interventions to manage ICP.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.1 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, HCO3: 24 mEq/L, BUN: 20 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL, Glucose: 110 mg/dL, INR: 2.5, Platelets: 180,000/uL, WBC: 9,000/uL

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Warfarin 5mg PO daily, Lisinopril 10mg PO daily, Atorvastatin 40mg PO daily, Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h PRN for headache, Hydralazine 10mg IV PRN for SBP >180, Mannitol 25g IV q6h PRN for increased ICP (MD order to initiate if signs of increased ICP are present)

rationale.correct: Maintaining the head of the bed (HOB) at 30 degrees promotes venous drainage from the brain, reducing ICP. Administering Mannitol, an osmotic diuretic, helps to reduce cerebral edema and ICP. Frequent neurological assessments, including GCS and pupillary response, are essential to monitor for changes in ICP and guide further interventions. Assessing motor strength is also crucial in determining the progression of stroke and any further deterioration.
rationale.incorrect: Lowering the HOB would increase ICP. While stool softeners can prevent straining, they do not directly address ICP. Normal saline bolus could worsen cerebral edema. Vital signs alone are not sufficient for a complete neurological assessment; GCS and pupillary response are vital. Waiting to assess motor strength could delay necessary interventions.
clinicalPearls: Early recognition and management of increased ICP in stroke patients are crucial for preventing secondary brain injury.
Always consider the patient's underlying medical conditions and current medications when planning interventions.

questionTrap.trap: The question focuses on immediate interventions for increased ICP, tempting test-takers to select options that address other aspects of stroke care or are less direct interventions for ICP.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully evaluate each option and prioritize interventions that directly reduce ICP based on the patient's current clinical status and the provided data.

mnemonic.title: ICP Management
mnemonic.expansion: ELEVATE (Elevate HOB, Limit fluids, Evaluate neuro status, Ventilate/oxygenate, Avoid straining, Treat fever, Ensure BP control)

options: Maintain head of bed at 30 degrees
Assess GCS and pupillary response q1h
Wait to assess motor strength until next shift
